title: 114_hr4180
content: The Act titled "Fraud Reduction and Data Analytics Act of 2015" defines terms like "agency" and "improper payment" and establishes financial and administrative controls related to fraud and improper payments. The "Fraud Reduction and Data Analytics Act of 2015" mandates the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to establish guidelines for agencies to prevent, detect, and respond to fraud, incorporating leading practices from a Government Accountability Office report. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with the Comptroller General of the United States, may modify guidelines periodically as necessary. Agencies must establish financial and administrative controls, including evaluating fraud risks, monitoring fraud trends, and continuously improving fraud prevention controls. Each agency must report to Congress on their progress in implementing financial and administrative controls, fraud risk principles, and Office of Management and Budget guidelines for the first 3 fiscal years after the enactment of the Act. Each agency must report to Congress on their progress in implementing financial and administrative controls, fraud risk principles, and Office of Management and Budget guidelines. This includes identifying risks and vulnerabilities to fraud in various areas such as payroll, beneficiary payments, grants, contracts, and purchase/travel cards, as well as establishing strategies to curb fraud. If the Act is enacted less than 180 days before the agency's annual financial report is due, the agency may include the required report in the following year's financial report. SEC. 4. WORKING GROUP. Establishment of a working group by the Office of Management and Budget within 180 days of the Act's enactment to improve sharing of financial controls, best practices for fraud detection, and data analytics techniques. The group will include the Controller of the Office of Management and Budget, Chief Financial Officers of agencies, and other relevant parties determined by the Director. The working group established under the Act shall consult with relevant experts, hold at least 4 meetings per year, and submit a plan for a Federal interagency library of data analytics within 270 days.
